partial_orders.reason: Both edits modify the same flag definition for 'steps_per_loop' within the same function. Edit 0 changes the default value from 1 to None, and Edit 1 updates the help text to explain what happens when the value is not set (None). These edits are directly related to the same symbol and represent a coordinated change where the default value change necessitates updating the documentation to explain the new behavior. The changed lines are part of the same flag definition construct, making this a synchronized modification.

These edits are bi-directional neighbours because they both reference the exact same symbol 'steps_per_loop' and form a cohesive parameter handling change. Edit 0 changes the default value of the steps_per_loop parameter from 1 to None in the function signature, while Edit 1 adds logic to handle the case when steps_per_loop is None/falsy by setting it to an appropriate default value. After making either edit, the other becomes the immediate next mechanical step - if you change the default to None without adding the handling logic, the function would break when steps_per_loop is None; if you add the None-handling logic without changing the default, the new logic would never execute. Both edits reference the same steps_per_loop parameter symbol and together implement a single coherent change to make the parameter's default behavior more intelligent.
